elements.content: A series of Mn(II), Cd(II), and Co(II) metal–organic frameworks, namely, {[Mn(L1)(NCS)2(CH3OH)2]·2(CH3OH)} n (1), {[Mn(L2)2(NCS)2(CH3OH)2]} n (2), {[Mn(L3)2(NCS)2]·0.5(CH3OH)·4.5H2O} n (3), {[Cd(L1)(I)2]·3(H2O)} n (4), {[Cd(L2)(I)2]} n (5), {[Cd(L3)(NCS)2]·2.5(H2O)} n (6), {[Co(L1)2(NCS)2]·4(H2O)} n (7), {[Co(L2)2(NCS)2]·(HCCl3) } n (8), and {[Co(L3)2(NCS)2]·3(H2O)} n (9) (where L1 = N,N′-bis(4-pyridylmethyl)-pyromellitic diimide, L2 = N,N′-bis(3-pyridylmethyl)-pyromellitic diimide, L3 = N,N′-bis(4-pyridylmethyl)-naphthalene diimide), were synthesized and structurally characterized by elemental analyses, thermogravimetric (TG) analyses, powder X-ray diffraction, IR spectroscopy, and single-crystal X-ray diffraction. In Mn(II) complexes 1–3, L1 connects the adjacent metal centers to form an infinite one-dimensional (1D) zigzag coordination polymeric chain, L2 acts as a monodentate ligand to give mononuclear coordination motifs, while L3 bridges two metal ions to generate two-dimensional (2D) networks of the (4, 4) net topology containing rhombic grids. In Cd(II) complexes 4–6, L1, L2, and L3 act as bidentate ligands and coordinate with two metal ions to form three different coordination polymers that display diversified structures, that is, infinite 1D zigzag chain in 4, single-stranded double helical chain in 5, and 2D networks of the (4, 4) net in 6. For three Co(II) complexes, 7 is a three-dimensional (3D) framework with 3-fold interpenetrating dia topology, while 8 and 9 have similar two-dimensional (2D) networks of the (4, 4) net topology. The results show that the conformation and coordination mode of organic ligands and the coordination geometry of metal centers play important roles in determining the structure and topology of the complexes. Furthermore, the gas sorption properties were measured, and complex 7 shows a highly selective sorption behavior toward CO2, which can be a promising candidate as adsorbents for CO2/N2 separation. In addition, the luminescence properties of 5–6 were studied in the solid state at room temperature.

elements.content: Nine metal−organic frameworks were assembled from three large semirigid ditopic ligands with two relatively flexible pyridyl arms, which coordinates with Mn(II), Cd(II), and Co(II) ions in different ways, affording a series of coordination polymers varying from discrete (0D), one-dimensional (1D) to three-dimensional (3D). Our findings may bring new insights and an important impetus to crystal engineering.
elements.clean_text: Nine metal-organic frameworks were assembled from three large semirigid ditopic ligands with two relatively flexible pyridyl arms, which coordinates with Mn(II), Cd(II), and Co(II) ions in different ways, affording a series of coordination polymers varying from discrete (0D), one-dimensional (1D) to three-dimensional (3D). Our findings may bring new insights and an important impetus to crystal engineering.

elements.content: Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) represent a fast growing area in coordination chemistry and supramolecular chemistry due to their intriguing architectures and topologies, as well as their potential applications in molecular recognition, ion exchange, adsorption, fluorescence, catalysis, and magnetic properties. However, the rational design and synthesis of MOFs with unique structure and function still remain a long-term challenge. Many factors such as the coordination environment of metal centers, the donor sets of ligands, solvent molecules, temperature, templates, counteranions, etc. can affect the final architectures. In particular, the structures of the ligands and the coordination fashions of metal ions play key roles in the self-assembly process of MOFs because deliberate modifications on the organic ligand, such as the length, flexibility, and symmetry, or coordination restraints on metal ions can dramatically change the ultimate structural topologies of the coordination frameworks. Moreover, metal–ligand coordination bonding and various kinds of intermolecular weak interactions are vital in the self-assembly process, which depend in most cases on the functionality and the geometry of the organic ligand used in the assembly. Therefore, understanding of influencing factors in self-assembly based on complementary and explicit interactions between building blocks is helpful to generate well-defined products with unique structure and function.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) represent a fast growing area in coordination chemistry and supramolecular chemistry due to their intriguing architectures and topologies, as well as their potential applications in molecular recognition, ion exchange, adsorption, fluorescence, catalysis, and magnetic properties. However, the rational design and synthesis of MOFs with unique structure and function still remain a long-term challenge. Many factors such as the coordination environment of metal centers, the donor sets of ligands, solvent molecules, temperature, templates, counteranions, etc. can affect the final architectures. In particular, the structures of the ligands and the coordination fashions of metal ions play key roles in the self-assembly process of MOFs because deliberate modifications on the organic ligand, such as the length, flexibility, and symmetry, or coordination restraints on metal ions can dramatically change the ultimate structural topologies of the coordination frameworks. Moreover, metal-ligand coordination bonding and various kinds of intermolecular weak interactions are vital in the self-assembly process, which depend in most cases on the functionality and the geometry of the organic ligand used in the assembly. Therefore, understanding of influencing factors in self-assembly based on complementary and explicit interactions between building blocks is helpful to generate well-defined products with unique structure and function.

elements.content: The nitrogen-donor ligands have been intensely investigated as ligands for the construction of novel MOFs. Our group has been working on the supramolecular synthesis of various coordination assemblies with semirigid ligands containing a freely rotatable methylene (−CH2−) juncture between a rigid spacer and pyridyl/benzimidazolyl rings, and a great diversity of discrete molecular architectures or infinite coordination polymers have been constructed. Taking into account that systematic investigation of the influence of the rigid spacer and substituent position of N-donor diimide ligands on the formation of coordination frameworks is scarce so far, we prepared three pyridyl donor diimide ligands, namely, N,N′-bis(4-pyridylmethyl)-pyromellitic diimide (L1), N,N′-bis(3-pyridylmethyl)-pyromellitic diimide (L2), N,N′-bis(4-pyridylmethyl)-naphthalene diimide (L3), which have different substituent groups and rigid spacers (), in an effort to investigate their supramolecular coordination chemistry. Nine MOFs have been assembled from these three pyridyl ligands which coordinate with Mn(II), Cd(II), and Co(II) ions in different ways to afford a series of coordination polymers varying from discrete (0D), one-dimensional (1D) to three-dimensional (3D) (Scheme ). By careful structural analyses of 1–9, we found that various coordination modes adopted by these N-donor ligands of different rigid spacer and substituent position are crucial factors for the formation of the different structures.

Our group has been working on the supramolecular synthesis of various coordination assemblies with semirigid ligands containing a freely rotatable methylene (-CH2-) juncture between a rigid spacer and pyridyl/benzimidazolyl rings, and a great diversity of discrete molecular architectures or infinite coordination polymers have been constructed. Taking into account that systematic investigation of the influence of the rigid spacer and substituent position of N-donor diimide ligands on the formation of coordination frameworks is scarce so far, we prepared three pyridyl donor diimide ligands, namely, N,N'-bis(4-pyridylmethyl)-pyromellitic diimide (L1), N,N'-bis(3-pyridylmethyl)-pyromellitic diimide (L2), N,N'-bis(4-pyridylmethyl)-naphthalene diimide (L3), which have different substituent groups and rigid spacers (), in an effort to investigate their supramolecular coordination chemistry. Nine MOFs have been assembled from these three pyridyl ligands which coordinate with Mn(II), Cd(II), and Co(II) ions in different ways to afford a series of coordination polymers varying from discrete (0D), one-dimensional (1D) to three-dimensional (3D) (Scheme ). By careful structural analyses of 1-9, we found that various coordination modes adopted by these N-donor ligands of different rigid spacer and substituent position are crucial factors for the formation of the different structures.

elements.content: All materials were reagent grade obtained from commercial sources and used without further purification, and solvents were dried by standard procedures. The L1, L2, and L3 ligands were prepared according to previous literature methods, respectively. Elemental analyses (C, H, N, S) were carried out with a Perkin-Elmer 240C elemental analyzer. Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra were recorded from KBr pellets in the range of 4000–400 cm–1 on a VECTOR 22 spectrometer. The powder X-ray diffraction (PRXD) was recorded on a Bruker D8 ADVANCE diffractometer (Cu Kα, 1.5418 Å) at 40 kV and 40 mA. Thermal analyses were performed on a TGA V5.1A Dupont 2100 instrument from room temperature to 800 °C with a heating rate of 10 °C min–1 in the air, and the data are consistent with the structures. Fluorescence measurements were performed on a Czemy-Turer FLS920 luminescence spectrometer. The adsorption isotherms of CO2 (at 195 K), N2, and H2 (at 77 K) were measured by using BELmax 00027 adsorption equipment (BEL Japan). An exactly measured amount of the sample was introduced into the gas sorption instrument after the sample was pre-desolvated in a Schlenk tube at 120 °C under a vacuum for 24 h. The adsorbate was placed into the sample tube, then the change of the pressure was monitored, and the degree of adsorption was determined by the decrease of the pressure at the equilibrium state. The sorption properties were analyzed using Autosorb 1 for Windows 1.24 software.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Physical Measurements

All materials were reagent grade obtained from commercial sources and used without further purification, and solvents were dried by standard procedures. The L1, L2, and L3  ligands were prepared according to previous literature methods, respectively. Elemental analyses (C, H, N, S) were carried out with a Perkin-Elmer 240C elemental analyzer. Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra were recorded from KBr pellets in the range of 4000-400 cm-1 on a VECTOR 22 spectrometer. The powder X-ray diffraction (PRXD) was recorded on a Bruker D8 ADVANCE diffractometer (Cu Kα, 1.5418 Å) at 40 kV and 40 mA. Thermal analyses were performed on a TGA V5.1A Dupont 2100 instrument from room temperature to 800 °C with a heating rate of 10 °C min-1 in the air, and the data are consistent with the structures. Fluorescence measurements were performed on a Czemy-Turer FLS920 luminescence spectrometer. The adsorption isotherms of CO2 (at 195 K), N2, and H2 (at 77 K) were measured by using BELmax 00027 adsorption equipment (BEL Japan). An exactly measured amount of the sample was introduced into the gas sorption instrument after the sample was pre-desolvated in a Schlenk tube at 120 °C under a vacuum for 24 h. The adsorbate was placed into the sample tube, then the change of the pressure was monitored, and the degree of adsorption was determined by the decrease of the pressure at the equilibrium state. The sorption properties were analyzed using Autosorb 1 for Windows 1.24 software.

elements.content: A mixture of MnCl2·4H2O (19.8 mg, 0.1 mmol), L1 (40.0 mg, 0.1 mmol), NaSCN (8.5 mg, 0.1 mmol) in CH3OH (6.0 mL), and CHCl3 (12.0 mL) was stirred and then sealed in a 20 mL Teflon-lined autoclave. The autoclave was heated to 110 °C and held at that temperature for 7 days, and then cooled to 80 °C and maintained at that temperature for 1 day, followed by further cooling to room temperature. Yellow crystals of 1 were collected in 25% yield based on ligand. Anal. Calcd. for C28H30N6O8S2Mn: C, 48.21; H, 4.33; N, 12.05; S, 9.19. Found: C, 47.86; H, 4.83; N, 12.41; S, 8.93%. elements.content: Phase purity of complexes 1–9 was checked by powder XRD measurements. The bulk samples of all complexes except 1, 4, and 8 gave satisfactory patterns matching those of the simulated ones from the single-crystal data, indicating formation of a single product, while measured XRD patterns of complexes 1, 4, and 8 obviously deviate from the simulated ones, which may be caused by phased transition occurring in open air due to escape of solvated molecules from the crystal lattice at room temperature. However, the chemical composition of these complexes has been verified by elemental analyses with carefully and quickly picked single crystals.

However, the chemical composition of these complexes has been verified by elemental analyses with carefully and quickly picked single crystals.

elements.content: The diffraction data were collected on a Oxford Gemini S Ultra diffractometer equipped with Cu–Kα radiation (λ = 1.54178 Å) for complexes 1, 3, and 7, or on the same diffractometer equipped with Mo–Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) for complexes 2, 4, 5, 6, 8, and 9 at 150 K (5, at 298 K) by using φ and ω scans. Analytical adsorption corrections were applied for complexes 2 and 3. Multiscan adsorption corrections were applied for all others. The structures were solved by the direct methods (SHELXS) and refined by the full matrix least-squares method against F o 2 using the SHELXTL software. The coordinates of the non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. Most of hydrogen atoms were introduced in calculated positions and refined with fixed geometry with respect to their carrier atoms, and the water hydrogen atoms have been not added. Details of the crystal parameters, data collections, and refinement for nine complexes 1–9 are summarized in . Hydrogen-bonding data of 1 and 2 complexes are listed in . Further details are provided in . CCDC numbers are 795985–795993.
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Data Collection and Structure Refinement

The diffraction data were collected on a Oxford Gemini S Ultra diffractometer equipped with Cu-Kα radiation (λ = 1.54178 Å) for complexes 1, 3, and 7, or on the same diffractometer equipped with Mo-Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) for complexes 2, 4, 5, 6, 8, and 9 at 150 K (5, at 298 K) by using φ and ω scans. Analytical adsorption corrections were applied for complexes 2 and 3. Multiscan adsorption corrections were applied for all others. The structures were solved by the direct methods (SHELXS) and refined by the full matrix least-squares method against F o 2 using the SHELXTL software. The coordinates of the non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. Most of hydrogen atoms were introduced in calculated positions and refined with fixed geometry with respect to their carrier atoms, and the water hydrogen atoms have been not added. Details of the crystal parameters, data collections, and refinement for nine complexes 1-9 are summarized in . Hydrogen-bonding data of 1 and 2 complexes are listed in . Further details are provided in . CCDC numbers are 795985-795993.

elements.content: The common structural feature in complexes 1–3 is that Mn(II) adopts a distorted octahedral coordination sphere which is defined by two N atoms from two SCN – anions on the apexes, but the ligand linkers between them are different in these three complexes. Complex 1 crystallizes in the triclinic system with space group P1̅. Its asymmetric unit contains an Mn(II) ion, one L1 ligand, two coordinating methanol molecules, one guest methanol molecule, and two coordinating NCS – anions. As shown in Figure a, the Mn(II) center is coordinated with two N atoms from two independent L1 ligands and two O atoms from two independent methanol molecules in the equatorial plane. The Mn–N and Mn–O bond lengths range from 2.309(6) to 2.313 (7) Å and 2.708(1) to 2.712(1) Å, respectively. As a ditopic ligand, L1 features in a large rigid spacer of three fused rings and two flexible Py arms. Since the two Py arms can rotate freely around the methylene groups (−CH2−), two main conformations are possible, namely, Z-mode with two Py rings at two sides of the spacer, or U-mode with two Py rings at the same side of the spacer (). The L1 ligand adopts the Z-mode conformation acting as a bridge between two Mn(II) ions which in turn connect two different ligands, and the building blocks in complex 1 are the [Mn(L1)(NCS)2(CH3OH)2] units which are connected in a zigzag way to form a 1D polymeric chain. These individual 1D chains, between which there are guest methanol molecules, are arranged in parallel with each other and further linked by weak nonclassical hydrogen bonds (Figure c). It is the guest methanol molecules that act as hydrogen bond acceptors to form O–H···O (O···O 2.636 Å, angle 170.57 (3)°) hydrogen bonds. In addition, O–H···S (O···S 3.238 Å, angle 172.42 (5)°) hydrogen bonds are formed between NCS – anions and methanol molecules, and therefore the overall crystal packing is sustained by above O–H···O and O–H···S hydrogen bonds to direct arrangement of the 1D coordination polymers in the crystal lattice, leading to a 2D hydrogen-bonding layer. Such layers are in parallel packed in the [001] direction and some solvated methanol molecules are encapsulated in the channels between the layers ().
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Structure Description of Mn(II) Complexes 1-3 

The common structural feature in complexes 1-3 is that Mn(II) adopts a distorted octahedral coordination sphere which is defined by two N atoms from two SCN -  anions on the apexes, but the ligand linkers between them are different in these three complexes. Complex 1 crystallizes in the triclinic system with space group P1̅. Its asymmetric unit contains an Mn(II) ion, one L1 ligand, two coordinating methanol molecules, one guest methanol molecule, and two coordinating NCS -  anions. As shown in Figure a, the Mn(II) center is coordinated with two N atoms from two independent L1 ligands and two O atoms from two independent methanol molecules in the equatorial plane. The Mn-N and Mn-O bond lengths range from 2.309(6) to 2.313 (7) Å and 2.708(1) to 2.712(1) Å, respectively. As a ditopic ligand, L1 features in a large rigid spacer of three fused rings and two flexible Py arms. Since the two Py arms can rotate freely around the methylene groups (-CH2-), two main conformations are possible, namely, Z-mode with two Py rings at two sides of the spacer, or U-mode with two Py rings at the same side of the spacer (). The L1 ligand adopts the Z-mode conformation acting as a bridge between two Mn(II) ions which in turn connect two different ligands, and the building blocks in complex 1 are the [Mn(L1)(NCS)2(CH3OH)2] units which are connected in a zigzag way to form a 1D polymeric chain. These individual 1D chains, between which there are guest methanol molecules, are arranged in parallel with each other and further linked by weak nonclassical hydrogen bonds (Figure c). It is the guest methanol molecules that act as hydrogen bond acceptors to form O-H⋅⋅⋅O (O⋅⋅⋅O 2.636 Å, angle 170.57 (3)°) hydrogen bonds. In addition, O-H⋅⋅⋅S (O⋅⋅⋅S 3.238 Å, angle 172.42 (5)°) hydrogen bonds are formed between NCS -  anions and methanol molecules, and therefore the overall crystal packing is sustained by above O-H⋅⋅⋅O and O-H⋅⋅⋅S hydrogen bonds to direct arrangement of the 1D coordination polymers in the crystal lattice, leading to a 2D hydrogen-bonding layer. Such layers are in parallel packed in the [001] direction and some solvated methanol molecules are encapsulated in the channels between the layers ().

elements.content: To investigate the impact of substituent position of N-donor diimide ligands on the structural diversity of the assembled frameworks, L2 which has four conformations (), instead of L1, was used in the reaction and complex 2 was successfully isolated. Complex 2 crystallizes in the triclinic system with space group P1̅. Its asymmetric unit contains an Mn(II) ion, two L2 ligands, two coordinating methanol molecules, and two coordinating NCS – anions (Figure a). The central Mn(II) ion is coordinated by two N atoms from two independent NCS - anions and two O atoms from two independent methanol molecules in the equatorial plane, and two N atoms from two independent L2 ligands on the apexes. It is clear that the coordination motif is a discrete mononuclear complex. Surprisingly, although we add excess metal ions, one of the NPy atoms in the ligand still remains uncoordinated, and L2 takes on a Zt-mode conformation in 2 and serves as a monodentate ligand. Instead, the non-coordinating NPy atoms become effective hydrogen-bonding acceptors which assemble the mononuclear basic units into a 1D ribbon chain due to the formation of O–H···N (O···N 2.831 Å, angle 169.95 (3)°) hydrogen bonds.

elements.content: When L3 with a naphthalene ring as the rigid spacer, instead of L1 or L2, was used in the reaction, complex 3 with a different structure was obtained. Complex 3 crystallizes in the monoclinic system with space group C2/c. Its asymmetric unit contains an Mn(II) ion, two L3 ligands, two coordinating NCS – anions. The overall coordination geometry of the Mn(II) ion in 3 can be described as a distorted octahedron consisting of four NPy donors from four different ligands and two N atoms from two independent NCS – anions (Figure a). The two terminal Py groups in L3 take on the “Z-mode” conformation and link up two Mn(II) ions such that a 2D grid is formed. In this grid network, the metal ions serve as 4-connecting nodes and the L3 is in a linear linker to bridge Mn(II) ions, and then connections between the metal nodes and the L3 linkers alternately will give rise to a 2D (4, 4) topological network (Figure b). The rhombic grid has a size of about 494.72 Å2 with an Mn–Mn distance of 19.55 Å on all four edges; in the (4, 4) grid, there are π···π stacking interactions (centroid distance, 4.10 Å) between the naphthalene rings. The crystal packing analysis reveals weaving layers stack in a parallel fashion, and between the layers the CH3OH and H2O molecules are encapsulated (Figure c).

elements.content: Because the structure of coordination polymers can be influenced by various factors including the metal centers, we introduced another kind of metal center, Cd(II), to the reactions, and the complexes 4–6 were obtained. Complex 4 crystallizes in the monoclinic system with space group P21/c. Its asymmetric unit contains a Cd(II) ion, one L1 ligands, two coordinating I– anions, and one guest chloroform molecule. The building blocks in complex 4 are [CdL1I2] units which are connected in a zigzag way to form a 1D polymeric chain as shown in Figure a. The coordination geometry of the Cd (II) ion is a distorted tetrahedron, composed of two NPy atoms from two different ligands and two terminal I– anions. The NPy–Cd–NPy and I–Cd–I angles are 100.25(4)° and 132.56(3)°, respectively. The individual 1D zigzag chain in complex 4 is interleaving with adjacent chains and connected by intermolecular weak C–H···O hydrogen-bonds (H···O distance, 3.18 Å) between imido O atoms and H atoms of the pyridyl groups (), forming quadrangle channels which are occupied by bulky water molecules (Figure b).
elements.clean_text:
Structure Description of Cd(II) Complexes 4-6 

Because the structure of coordination polymers can be influenced by various factors including the metal centers, we introduced another kind of metal center, Cd(II), to the reactions, and the complexes 4-6 were obtained. Complex 4 crystallizes in the monoclinic system with space group P21/c. Its asymmetric unit contains a Cd(II) ion, one L1 ligands, two coordinating I- anions, and one guest chloroform molecule. The building blocks in complex 4 are [CdL1I2] units which are connected in a zigzag way to form a 1D polymeric chain as shown in Figure a. The coordination geometry of the Cd (II) ion is a distorted tetrahedron, composed of two NPy atoms from two different ligands and two terminal I- anions. The NPy-Cd-NPy and I-Cd-I angles are 100.25(4)° and 132.56(3)°, respectively. The individual 1D zigzag chain in complex 4 is interleaving with adjacent chains and connected by intermolecular weak C-H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen-bonds (H⋅⋅⋅O distance, 3.18 Å) between imido O atoms and H atoms of the pyridyl groups (), forming quadrangle channels which are occupied by bulky water molecules (Figure b).

elements.content: Complex 5 crystallizes in the monoclinic system with space group P21/c. Its asymmetric unit contains a Cd(II) ion, one L2 ligand, and two coordinating I– anions. The Cd (II) center is also four-coordinated in a distorted tetrahedral geometry composed of two N atoms from two independent L2 ligands and two I– anions, as shown in Figure a. The Cd–N and Cd–I bond lengths are 2.297(5) and 2.694(3) Å, respectively, and the N–Cd–I bond angles range from 111.3(1)° to 100.9(1)°. Compared with the metal environment in complex 4, the N–Cd–N angle (94.7(5)°) and I–Cd–I angle (125.6(1)°) in 5 are smaller than the corresponding N–Cd–N angle (100.2(1)°) and I–Cd–I angle (134.6(3)°) in 4, respectively. Moreover, the L2 ligand adopts the Uc conformation to bridge two Cd (II) ions, leading to the formation of a single-stranded double helical chain structure. These differences between 4 and 5 indicate that the different substituent position of N-donor ligands adopting various coordination modes have a remarkable influence on formation of the different structures around the metal center in the two complexes.

elements.content: Single-crystal structural determinations reveal that 6 crystallizes in C2/c space group. Its asymmetric unit contains a Cd(II) ion, one L3 ligand, two coordinating NCS - anions, and one chloroform molecule (Figure a). Each Cd(II) atom is coordinated by two nitrogen atoms from two different L3 ligands, two nitrogen atoms from different thiocyanates in the equatorial plane, and two sulfur atoms from the thiocyanates to give a distorted octahedral geometry. Complex 6 possesses a 1D infinite chain-like structure with each pair of adjacent Cd(II) atoms linked together by two μ2-SCN-N,S bridges propagating along the b axis direction with chair form eight-membered rings (Figure b) and the Cd···Cd separations of 5.885(6) Å. The two terminal Py groups in L3 take on the “Z” conformation and link up two Cd (II) ions such that a 2D grid is formed. In this grid network, the metal ions serve as 4-connecting nodes. If we use the center of N–N bond to represent the L3 node, N–S bond to represent two thiocyanates node, connections between the metal nodes, the L3 and thiocyanates nodes alternately will give rise to a 2D (4, 4) topological network as shown in Figure c; in the (4, 4) grid, there are π···π stacking interactions (centroid, 3.92 Å) between the naphthalene rings. In the crystal lattice, such 2D networks are stacked in parallel and separated by water molecules.

elements.content: When Mn(II) or Cd(II) ion was replaced by Co(II) ion, complexes 7–9 were obtained. Crystallographic analysis reveals that complex 7 crystallizes in the Fddd space group. Its asymmetric unit contains a Co(II) ion, two L1 ligands, and two coordinating NCS– anions (Figure a). Complex 7 is a 3-fold interpenetrated diamond network structure. The coordination geometry of Co(II) ion can be described as a distorted octahedron with four NPy donors from four different ligands and two N donors from two different NCS– anions. L1 takes on a “Z” conformation, providing NPy atoms as coordination donors to connect two Co(II) ions. In contrast to the 1D structures in 1 and 4 where two “Z” conformational ligands are oppositely arranged around the metal center, there are four ligands on the equatorial plane in 7, and the NPy–Co–NPy angles are 90.0(3)° and 180.0(2)°, respectively. If we use the center of N–N bond to represent the L1 node, the metal ions serve as 4-connecting nodes, and connections between the metal nodes and the L1 linkers alternately will give rise to a 3D diamond topological network as shown in Figure b. When an adamantane unit is chosen from a single network, there are two other unique adamantane units interpenetrating with the first one, which leads to the formation of 3-fold interpenetrated diamondoid networks (Figure c) containing incline meso-helical chains (P + M) with the angle of 60° (Figure d). The structure of 7 shows the balanced packing of left-handed and right-handed 4-fold helices of cationic -Co-L1-Co-L1- chains, extending in the direction of the b axis. The pitch of the helices is 51.7 Å (Figure e). The crystal packing analysis reveals diamond networks interpenetrating in a parallel fashion, and between the networks the H2O molecules are encapsulated (Figure f). Potential channels (6.52 × 5.63 Å2) are provided by such 3D framework to guest water and methanol molecules. The framework has a 5670 Å3 potential solvent accessible area (V void = 44% of the total crystal volume) estimated by PLATON.

elements.content: Complex 8 crystallizes in the triclinic system with space group P1̅. Its asymmetric unit contains a Co(II) ion, two L2 ligands, two coordinating NCS– anions, and one guest chloroform molecule. L2 takes on “Zt-mode” conformation, providing NPy atoms as coordination donors to connect two Co(II) ions. Similar to 7, the coordination geometry of Co(II) ion can be described as a distorted octahedron with four NPy donors from four different ligands and two N donors from two different NCS– anions (Figure a). However, the angle between Py arm and benzene ring in 8 is 80.0(2)° in contrast to 62.3(5)° in 7. Complex 8 is a 2D (4, 4) topological network as shown in Figure b. Since the grid in 8 consists of four metals and four ligands, spacious (4, 4) network is formed with the quadrangular grid having the lengths of Co–Co 18.656 Å and 14.605 Å, respectively. The crystal packing analysis reveals the layers stacked in a parallel fashion, and in the layers CHCl3 molecules are encapsulated (Figure c).
elements.clean_text: Complex 8 crystallizes in the triclinic system with space group P1̅. Its asymmetric unit contains a Co(II) ion, two L2 ligands, two coordinating NCS- anions, and one guest chloroform molecule. L2 takes on "Zt-mode" conformation, providing NPy atoms as coordination donors to connect two Co(II) ions. Similar to 7, the coordination geometry of Co(II) ion can be described as a distorted octahedron with four NPy donors from four different ligands and two N donors from two different NCS- anions (Figure a). However, the angle between Py arm and benzene ring in 8 is 80.0(2)° in contrast to 62.3(5)° in 7. Complex 8 is a 2D (4, 4) topological network as shown in Figure b. Since the grid in 8 consists of four metals and four ligands, spacious (4, 4) network is formed with the quadrangular grid having the lengths of Co-Co 18.656 Å and 14.605 Å, respectively. The crystal packing analysis reveals the layers stacked in a parallel fashion, and in the layers CHCl3 molecules are encapsulated (Figure c).

elements.content: It is well-known that the N-donor ligands are good linkers in mediating and constructing MOFs with a specific structure. From above structural descriptions, we can see that the structural nature of L1, L2, and L3 ligands have a remarkable impact on the frameworks of the compounds. Because of their different flexibility and coordination modes, the structures of 1–9 are diversifed. Three ligands possess comparable structural features, but show different coordination behaviors. Ligands L1 and L2 differ in positions of the N-donors on the pyridyl groups, thus showing distinct angles and flexibility. Ligand L1 of 4-position N-donors can only display two possible conformations (Z- or U-mode), while ligand L2 of 3-positon N-donors can display four possible conformations (Zt-, Zc-, Ut-, or Uc-mode). In complexes 1 and 4, ligand L1 adopts the usual Z-mode conformation to bridge a two metal center, generating similar 1D chain-like structures. In contrast, ligand L2 takes on a Zt-mode conformation and serves as a monodentate ligand in 2, coordinating to one metal center with the other nitrogen atom forming hydrogen-bonds which assemble the mononuclear basic units into a 1D ribbon chain. In complex 8, L2 ligand also takes on Zt-mode conformation to generate a 2D (4, 4) network. However, in complex 5, L2 ligand adopts the Uc conformation to bridge two metal ions, leading to the formation of a single-stranded double helical chain structure. Ligand L3 has the same 4-position pyridyl donor groups as L1 but contains a larger aromatic naphthalene rigid spacer. Therefore, the π···π stacking interactions between the naphthalene rings play a primary role in directing the assembly process of the supramolecular complexes. In complexes 3 and 9, four L3 ligands coordinate to one metal center to form [M(L3)2] building blocks which are connected into a (4, 4) topological network sustained by π···π stacking. In complex 6, a similar 2D (4, 4) network is constructed from the [M(L3)] building blocks due to μ2-SCN-N,S bridge. In all three cases, ligand L3 takes the same Z-mode conformation.
elements.clean_text:
Structural Diversity and Dimensional Change

It is well-known that the N-donor ligands are good linkers in mediating and constructing MOFs with a specific structure. From above structural descriptions, we can see that the structural nature of L1, L2, and L3 ligands have a remarkable impact on the frameworks of the compounds. Because of their different flexibility and coordination modes, the structures of 1-9 are diversifed. Three ligands possess comparable structural features, but show different coordination behaviors. Ligands L1 and L2 differ in positions of the N-donors on the pyridyl groups, thus showing distinct angles and flexibility. Ligand L1 of 4-position N-donors can only display two possible conformations (Z- or U-mode), while ligand L2 of 3-positon N-donors can display four possible conformations (Zt-, Zc-, Ut-, or Uc-mode). In complexes 1 and 4, ligand L1 adopts the usual Z-mode conformation to bridge a two metal center, generating similar 1D chain-like structures. In contrast, ligand L2 takes on a Zt-mode conformation and serves as a monodentate ligand in 2, coordinating to one metal center with the other nitrogen atom forming hydrogen-bonds which assemble the mononuclear basic units into a 1D ribbon chain. In complex 8, L2 ligand also takes on Zt-mode conformation to generate a 2D (4, 4) network. However, in complex 5, L2 ligand adopts the Uc conformation to bridge two metal ions, leading to the formation of a single-stranded double helical chain structure. Ligand L3 has the same 4-position pyridyl donor groups as L1 but contains a larger aromatic naphthalene rigid spacer. Therefore, the π⋅⋅⋅π stacking interactions between the naphthalene rings play a primary role in directing the assembly process of the supramolecular complexes. In complexes 3 and 9, four L3 ligands coordinate to one metal center to form [M(L3)2] building blocks which are connected into a (4, 4) topological network sustained by π⋅⋅⋅π stacking. In complex 6, a similar 2D (4, 4) network is constructed from the [M(L3)] building blocks due to μ2-SCN-N,S bridge. In all three cases, ligand L3 takes the same Z-mode conformation.

elements.content: Three different metal ions, Mn(II), Co(II), and Cd(II) which usually exhibit distinct coordination geometric preference have been selected to assemble with the ligands L1–L3 with the intention of understanding their general coordination chemistry. However, only the L2 ligand can take on varied conformations when reacted with different metal salts, generating complexes 2, 5, and 8 as discrete 0D motif, 1D single-stranded double helical chain, and 2D (4, 4) topological network, respectively. This may be due to more flexible and versatile conformations of L2 in comparison with L1 and L3. Since Mn(II), Co(II), and Cd(II) metal ions all adopt resembling octahedral coordination geometry in the case of the same NCS– anions, the influence of metal ions on coordination assembly may be subject to a subtle synergistic effect from the structural nature of the conformation-tunable ditopic ligand as well as potential intermolecular interactions. In addition, counteranions also affect the assembly of supramolecular complexes. In Cd(II) complexes 4 and 5, anion I– coordinates to Cd(II) ions in terminal fashion, leading to the formation of 1D chain compounds. However, in Cd(II) complexes 6, anion NCS– ligates to Cd(II) ions in μ2-bridging fashion, resulting in the formation of a 2D layer compound. For the Mn(II) and Co(II) complexes, anion NCS– only coordinates to the metal ion in terminal η1-N mode. Meanwhile, different intermolecular weak interactions, such as hydrogen bonds and π···π stacking, also contribute to the formation of the supramolecular structures with different characters in the present series of complexes 1–9.

elements.content: The thermal stability of the coordination polymers was analyzed by recording thermogravimetric (TG) curves of selected complexes. As a representative, Figure shows the TG diagram of complex 7, {[Co(L1)2(NCS)2]·4(H2O)} n . Three main steps of weight losses were observed in the temperature range from 25 to 800 °C. The first step occurs in the range of 25–90 °C, amounting to about 6.7% and corresponding to the escape of water molecules (calculated 6.8%). The complex remains undecomposed up to 230 °C where the second weight loss starts. Complete decomposition of the complex finishes at about 640 °C. The general decomposition temperature of other complexes is in the range of 250–350 °C (Figure S2, ), which is typical for MOFs containing large organic ligands.
elements.clean_text:
Thermal Stability

The thermal stability of the coordination polymers was analyzed by recording thermogravimetric (TG) curves of selected complexes. As a representative, Figure  shows the TG diagram of complex 7, {[Co(L1)2(NCS)2]⋅4(H2O)} n . Three main steps of weight losses were observed in the temperature range from 25 to 800 °C. The first step occurs in the range of 25-90 °C, amounting to about 6.7% and corresponding to the escape of water molecules (calculated 6.8%). The complex remains undecomposed up to 230 °C where the second weight loss starts. Complete decomposition of the complex finishes at about 640 °C. The general decomposition temperature of other complexes is in the range of 250-350 °C (Figure S2, ), which is typical for MOFs containing large organic ligands.

elements.content: Photoluminescence of coordination polymers constructed from d10 metal centers have often been investigated for their potential applications in chemical sensors, photochemistry, and electroluminescent display. Therefore, the solid state emission spectra of complexes 5 and 6 and the corresponding free ligands L2 and L3 were measured at room temperature (Figure ). A broad emission band was observed at 425 nm for L2 and 437 nm for 5 (λex = 300 nm), respectively. Similarly, a wide emission band was observed at 562 nm for L3 and 575 nm for 6 (λex = 465 nm), respectively. Compared to those of free ligands, the emission maxima of complexes 5 and 6 are increased and slightly red-shifted. From the band shape and position, we speculate that the emission of the complexes is ligand centered (LC), which has been verified by the lifetime measurement for the ligand L3 and complex 6. As depicted in , both the ligand and complex show quite similar biexponential decays, τ1 = 0.44 and τ2 = 4.20 ns for L3, and τ1 = 0.86 and τ2 = 3.25 ns for complex 6. Such lifetime is typical for an organic compound with two aromatic moieties. The red shift and increasing intensity of the LC emissions in complexes compared to the free ligands are obviously caused by coordination of N-donor ligands to the metal centers, which effectively increases the ligand conformational rigidity and therefore results in a decrease in the loss of energy by radiationless decay.

Luminescent Properties

A broad emission band was observed at 425 nm for L2 and 437 nm for 5 (λex = 300 nm), respectively. Compared to those of free ligands, the emission maxima of complexes 5 and 6 are increased and slightly red-shifted. From the band shape and position, we speculate that the emission of the complexes is ligand centered (LC), which has been verified by the lifetime measurement for the ligand L3 and complex 6. As depicted in , both the ligand and complex show quite similar biexponential decays, τ1 = 0.44 and τ2 = 4.20 ns for L3, and τ1 = 0.86 and τ2 = 3.25 ns for complex 6. Such lifetime is typical for an organic compound with two aromatic moieties. The red shift and increasing intensity of the LC emissions in complexes compared to the free ligands are obviously caused by coordination of N-donor ligands to the metal centers, which effectively increases the ligand conformational rigidity and therefore results in a decrease in the loss of energy by radiationless decay.

elements.content: To verify the porosity of 7, which provides a void space composing 44% of the total crystal volume, the gas sorption properties were measured for N2 (kinetic diameter = 3.64 Å), H2 (2.8 Å), and CO2 (3.3 Å) gases, respectively. All adsorption isotherms show type I behavior as expected for materials with micropores (∼5 Å) (Figure ). Interestingly, 7 can adsorb a medium amount of CO2 at 1 atm and 195 K [24.6 cm3 g–1 (STP)], exhibiting noticeable sorption selectivity of CO2 over N2 [13.9 cm3 g–1 (STP)] and H2 [0.6 cm3 g–1 (STP)]. It was also observed that there is some sort of hysteresis between CO2 sorption/desorption curves, which might originate from the interactions of CO2 molecules with the host solid 7. The different adsorption capabilities for gases can be ascribed to the existence of a larger quadrupolar moment for CO2 (quadrupolar moment = 4.30 × 1026 esu cm2) than N2 (1.52 × 1026 esu cm2) and H2 (0.662 × 1026 esu cm2), thereby providing stronger framework-partial-charge/quadrupole interactions for CO2. The capture and separation of carbon dioxide are important for the safe storage of carbon into deep geological formations, and this selectivity is useful for CO2 separations from synthesis gas and flue gas mixtures.

Sorption Properties

To verify the porosity of 7, which provides a void space composing 44% of the total crystal volume, the gas sorption properties were measured for N2 (kinetic diameter = 3.64 Å), H2 (2.8 Å), and CO2 (3.3 Å) gases, respectively. All adsorption isotherms show type I behavior as expected for materials with micropores (~5 Å) (Figure ). Interestingly, 7 can adsorb a medium amount of CO2 at 1 atm and 195 K [24.6 cm3 g-1 (STP)], exhibiting noticeable sorption selectivity of CO2 over N2 [13.9 cm3 g-1 (STP)] and H2 [0.6 cm3 g-1 (STP)]. It was also observed that there is some sort of hysteresis between CO2 sorption/desorption curves, which might originate from the interactions of CO2 molecules with the host solid 7. The different adsorption capabilities for gases can be ascribed to the existence of a larger quadrupolar moment for CO2 (quadrupolar moment = 4.30 × 1026 esu cm2) than N2 (1.52 × 1026 esu cm2) and H2 (0.662 × 1026 esu cm2), thereby providing stronger framework-partial-charge/quadrupole interactions for CO2. The capture and separation of carbon dioxide are important for the safe storage of carbon into deep geological formations, and this selectivity is useful for CO2 separations from synthesis gas and flue gas mixtures.

elements.content: Three structurally related large semirigid ditopic ligands with two relatively flexible pyridyl arms and their Mn(II), Cd(II), and Co(II) complexes have been synthesized and structurally characterized. When reacted with different metal salts, different ligands can take on varied conformations to generate discrete 0D to polymeric 3D coordination structures, which are further stabilized by hydrogen bonds and π···π interactions in the crystal lattice. It is found that the structural nature, including the positions of the N-donors and the spacers of pyromellitic or naphthalene diimide, play a key role to determine the conformation and coordination mode of these ligands, leading to different building blocks for assembly of varied coordination polymers. The results demonstrate that these large semirigid ditopic ligands can be rationally used to construct novel MOFs with specific structure and properties, which may bring new insights and an important impetus to crystal engineering. In addition, the gas adsorption experiment indicates complex 7 can be used for CO2 separations from synthesis gas and flue gas mixtures, and the fluorescent emissions show that complexes 5 and 6 may be good candidates for photoactive materials.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

Three structurally related large semirigid ditopic ligands with two relatively flexible pyridyl arms and their Mn(II), Cd(II), and Co(II) complexes have been synthesized and structurally characterized. When reacted with different metal salts, different ligands can take on varied conformations to generate discrete 0D to polymeric 3D coordination structures, which are further stabilized by hydrogen bonds and π⋅⋅⋅π interactions in the crystal lattice. It is found that the structural nature, including the positions of the N-donors and the spacers of pyromellitic or naphthalene diimide, play a key role to determine the conformation and coordination mode of these ligands, leading to different building blocks for assembly of varied coordination polymers. The results demonstrate that these large semirigid ditopic ligands can be rationally used to construct novel MOFs with specific structure and properties, which may bring new insights and an important impetus to crystal engineering. In addition, the gas adsorption experiment indicates complex 7 can be used for CO2 separations from synthesis gas and flue gas mixtures, and the fluorescent emissions show that complexes 5 and 6 may be good candidates for photoactive materials.

{[Mn(L1)(NCS)2(CH3OH)2]⋅2(CH3OH)} n  (1)

A mixture of MnCl2⋅4H2O (19.8 mg, 0.1 mmol), L1 (40.0 mg, 0.1 mmol), NaSCN (8.5 mg, 0.1 mmol) in CH3OH (6.0 mL), and CHCl3 (12.0 mL) was stirred and then sealed in a 20 mL Teflon-lined autoclave. The autoclave was heated to 110 °C and held at that temperature for 7 days, and then cooled to 80 °C and maintained at that temperature for 1 day, followed by further cooling to room temperature. cln_elements.content:
When L3 with a naphthalene ring as the rigid spacer, instead of L1 or L2, was used in the reaction, complex 3 with a different structure was obtained. Complex 3 crystallizes in the monoclinic system with space group C2/c. Its asymmetric unit contains an Mn(II) ion, two L3 ligands, two coordinating NCS – anions. The overall coordination geometry of the Mn(II) ion in 3 can be described as a distorted octahedron consisting of four NPy donors from four different ligands and two N atoms from two independent NCS – anions (Figure a). The two terminal Py groups in L3 take on the “Z-mode” conformation and link up two Mn(II) ions such that a 2D grid is formed. In this grid network, the metal ions serve as 4-connecting nodes and the L3 is in a linear linker to bridge Mn(II) ions, and then connections between the metal nodes and the L3 linkers alternately will give rise to a 2D (4, 4) topological network (Figure b). The rhombic grid has a size of about 494.72 Å2 with an Mn–Mn distance of 19.55 Å on all four edges; in the (4, 4) grid, there are π···π stacking interactions (centroid distance, 4.10 Å) between the naphthalene rings. The crystal packing analysis reveals weaving layers stack in a parallel fashion, and between the layers the CH3OH and H2O molecules are encapsulated (Figure c).

Thermal Stability

The thermal stability of the coordination polymers was analyzed by recording thermogravimetric (TG) curves of selected complexes. As a representative, Figure shows the TG diagram of complex 7, {[Co(L1)2(NCS)2]·4(H2O)} n . Three main steps of weight losses were observed in the temperature range from 25 to 800 °C. The first step occurs in the range of 25–90 °C, amounting to about 6.7% and corresponding to the escape of water molecules (calculated 6.8%). The complex remains undecomposed up to 230 °C where the second weight loss starts. Complete decomposition of the complex finishes at about 640 °C. The general decomposition temperature of other complexes is in the range of 250–350 °C (Figure S2, ), which is typical for MOFs containing large organic ligands.

Luminescent Properties

Photoluminescence of coordination polymers constructed from d10 metal centers have often been investigated for their potential applications in chemical sensors, photochemistry, and electroluminescent display. Therefore, the solid state emission spectra of complexes 5 and 6 and the corresponding free ligands L2 and L3 were measured at room temperature (Figure ). A broad emission band was observed at 425 nm for L2 and 437 nm for 5 (λex = 300 nm), respectively. Similarly, a wide emission band was observed at 562 nm for L3 and 575 nm for 6 (λex = 465 nm), respectively. Compared to those of free ligands, the emission maxima of complexes 5 and 6 are increased and slightly red-shifted. From the band shape and position, we speculate that the emission of the complexes is ligand centered (LC), which has been verified by the lifetime measurement for the ligand L3 and complex 6. As depicted in , both the ligand and complex show quite similar biexponential decays, τ1 = 0.44 and τ2 = 4.20 ns for L3, and τ1 = 0.86 and τ2 = 3.25 ns for complex 6. Such lifetime is typical for an organic compound with two aromatic moieties. The red shift and increasing intensity of the LC emissions in complexes compared to the free ligands are obviously caused by coordination of N-donor ligands to the metal centers, which effectively increases the ligand conformational rigidity and therefore results in a decrease in the loss of energy by radiationless decay.

Sorption Properties

To verify the porosity of 7, which provides a void space composing 44% of the total crystal volume, the gas sorption properties were measured for N2 (kinetic diameter = 3.64 Å), H2 (2.8 Å), and CO2 (3.3 Å) gases, respectively. All adsorption isotherms show type I behavior as expected for materials with micropores (∼5 Å) (Figure ). Interestingly, 7 can adsorb a medium amount of CO2 at 1 atm and 195 K [24.6 cm3 g–1 (STP)], exhibiting noticeable sorption selectivity of CO2 over N2 [13.9 cm3 g–1 (STP)] and H2 [0.6 cm3 g–1 (STP)]. It was also observed that there is some sort of hysteresis between CO2 sorption/desorption curves, which might originate from the interactions of CO2 molecules with the host solid 7. The different adsorption capabilities for gases can be ascribed to the existence of a larger quadrupolar moment for CO2 (quadrupolar moment = 4.30 × 1026 esu cm2) than N2 (1.52 × 1026 esu cm2) and H2 (0.662 × 1026 esu cm2), thereby providing stronger framework-partial-charge/quadrupole interactions for CO2. The capture and separation of carbon dioxide are important for the safe storage of carbon into deep geological formations, and this selectivity is useful for CO2 separations from synthesis gas and flue gas mixtures.

metadata.title: Structural Diversity of a Series of Mn(II), Cd(II), and Co(II) Complexes with Pyridine Donor Diimide Ligands
